Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Husky Teach is a Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Phase I project that will recruit, prepare, and support a diverse and talented group of professionals to become science and math teachers in high-needs settings. This Phase 1 project combines research activity by marine scientists with best teacher preparation practices. The project leverages local expertise to prepare post-graduates and career changers so they excel during their initial years in teaching positions in high-need schools. The project will advance understandings about integrating STEM subject matter mentoring into the goal of preparing teachers for high-need schools. Combining expertise from marine scientists with coursework emphasizing access and equity to STEM careers is unique to this project, the outcomes of which would inform similar practices in at other science teacher preparation sites.

Best teacher preparation practices combined with the marine research programs at the Avery Point campus provide a seedbed of science learning opportunities for future science teachers. The HuskyTeach project aligns with other strategic investments by the University of Connecticut and the State. Noyce recipients will progress through the established program with the addition of iteratively working with STEM Mentors. The goals of the HuskyTeach project include: 1) recruiting 24 high-quality STEM professionals for science teaching careers, 2) integrating STEM content with education training to prepare future science teachers, 3) providing experiences and resources to prepare science teachers to work in high-needs schools, 4) increasing the diversity of the science teaching workforce, and 5) using multiple data sources to inform the improvements to STEM teacher preparation. Participants will integrate content acquired from marine science research into curriculum modules developed in association with education coursework. Key evaluation and assessment measurements of this project will chart attitudinal shifts and dispositions over time, with particular focus on data-informed decisions with respect to teaching science in high-needs schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The HuskyTeach project was designed to provide financial and intellectual support to those seeking certification to teach STEM in high-needs schools. Ultimately, Noyce awards were supplied to 25 individuals who held undergraduate degrees in STEM fields. Two individuals withdrew before fulfilling all course and certification requirements. All the other HuskyTeach recipients, except for one, took fulltime teaching positions in schools where more than forty-percent of students qualified for free/reduced-priced meals based on family income. To date, all of these recipients have fulfilled or are on-track to fulfill the stipulation of teaching two years in a high needs middle or high school; only two left their high needs school after completing their teaching obligations.

 

There are several reasons that this Noyce project experienced success with preparing this number of teachers. First, the program itself was exclusively focused on STEM teaching in diverse settings. All coursework emphasized the opportunities and challenges this created. This is a departure from other programs that only offer a few courses specific to STEM and where equity is only occasionally addressed. This emphasis was made during recruitment sessions and was integrated into the admissions interviews. We believe this signaling alerted potential Noyce recipients to these demands and perhaps discouraged those who might not share those commitments. Second, Noyce recipients moved through the program as a cohort and as a result, jointly developed substantive understandings about the challenges of reducing achievement gaps, of providing culturally responsive education, and the value in drawing upon local resources to support STEM instruction. Third, the one-year program culminated with a semester long research study that was framed by social capital and supplemented by coursework on teacher leadership. Since student teaching occurred in fall (following an intensive summer of classes and clinic experience), the final semester afforded a reflective time to recognize the intellectual aspects of the STEM teaching profession. A fourth cause for success was that size of the Noyce stipend. A previous Noyce project (at a different regional campus and directed by a different faculty member) the stipend was half the amount awarded by HuskyTeach. The potential burden of defaulting on the stipend likely discouraged those who were unsure they wanted to teach in high needs schools.
